prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for wearing earbuds and occasionally checking my phone during a church mass that I am forced to go to even though I am an atheist?
My parents have recently had a interest in going to church for the past month or so, so every Sunday, they force me to attend mass with them. I have told them multiple times that I don't believe in what they believe, but they brush it off and force me to come anyways. So this time, I brought earbuds and put on an album to listen to (Stokeley by Ski Mask the Slump God is great; listen to it) because I wanted to listen to my music instead. I would also text my friend every 15 minutes or so. During the entire mass, my mom shot me dirty looks the whole time and later told me on the ride home that I have a horribly negative attitude and that I should enjoy things more (even though I have told them countless times that I don't believe in what they do and dislike attending church.

Am I just being a bitch or are my parents at fault?
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

On the other hand, the parents might feel that attending church is a family activity, and even if the child doesn't believe, they should still participate to show respect. The parents might not be aware that forcing someone to attend religious services can be problematic, especially if the person is an atheist.

So, is the child wrong? Well, their actions during the service could be seen as disrespectful in the church setting. But they're also reacting to being forced into an environment they find uncomfortable. The parents are at fault for not respecting the child's beliefs and autonomy. However, the child's behavior during the service might still be inconsiderate towards the parents' wishes and the norms of the church.

I think the child is partially right to feel forced into something they don't believe in, but their actions during the service could be seen as disrespectful, which might make them at least partially in the wrong. The parents are definitely in the wrong for not respecting the child's preferences. But the question is specifically about the author (the child) being in the wrong.
